title: Accounting
description: FBLA Objective Test covering accounting fundamentals, financial statements, and business transactions.

questions.text: What is the purpose of journalizing in accounting?
options: To record business transactions in chronological order

questions.text: Which of the following is considered an asset?
What does the accounting equation represent?
Which financial statement shows a company's revenues and expenses?
What is the main purpose of a balance sheet?
options: To show cash inflows and outflows
To report the financial position of a business at a point in time

questions.text: Which type of account is 'Accounts Receivable'?
In double-entry accounting, every transaction affects how many accounts?
Which of the following would be found in the credit column of a trial balance?
What is the result of posting entries to the ledger?
Which account is increased with a debit?
What is the purpose of a worksheet in accounting?
options: To organize data for financial statements

questions.text: Which document is used to compare a company's checkbook with its bank statement?
What is a payroll register?
options: A tool for computing loan interest
A record of employee pay details

questions.text: What is a sole proprietorship?
options: A business owned by one person

questions.text: What does depreciation represent in accounting?
options: The expense of using long-term assets

questions.text: Which of these is an intangible asset?
How is net income calculated?
What does the term 'liability' refer to?
What does GAAP stand for?
Which of these is not a financial statement?
What type of account is 'Unearned Revenue'?
What is the primary purpose of adjusting entries?
options: To update account balances before financial statements

questions.text: What is a trial balance used for?
What does the matching principle in accounting require?
options: Matching expenses with revenues in the same period

questions.text: What is the correct order of the accounting cycle?
options: Analyzing, Journalizing, Posting, Trial Balance, Adjusting Entries, Financial Statements

questions.text: What is a petty cash fund used for?
How are expenses recorded in the accounting equation?
What is the purpose of closing entries?
options: To prepare permanent accounts for the next period

questions.text: What does 'accrued expense' mean?
options: A recorded liability that has not been paid yet

questions.text: Which of the following is considered an operating activity in the statement of cash flows?
Which of the following best describes internal controls in accounting?
options: Procedures to ensure accuracy and prevent fraud

questions.text: What is a contra asset account?
options: An account that offsets an asset account

questions.text: What does the term 'fiscal year' refer to?
options: The period from January to December
A 12-month period used for financial reporting

questions.text: What type of account is 'Sales Returns and Allowances'?
How are prepaid expenses recorded on the balance sheet?
What is a common depreciation method used in accounting?
What is the primary purpose of a post-closing trial balance?
options: To check balances after closing entries are made

questions.text: Which of the following is a temporary account?
What is the effect of an adjusting entry for accrued revenue?
options: Decrease an asset and increase a liability
Increase an asset and increase revenue

questions.text: Which document provides a record of all business transactions in chronological order?
What is the purpose of the income summary account?
options: To transfer net income or loss to capital

questions.text: When preparing a bank reconciliation, which item would be subtracted from the book balance?
Which financial statement includes the heading 'For the Year Ended'?
Which principle requires businesses to record expenses in the same period as the revenues they help to generate?
What is the result of underestimating depreciation expense?
options: Overstated expenses and understated net income
Understated expenses and overstated net income

questions.text: In accounting, what does the term 'posting' refer to?
options: Transferring data from the journal to the ledger

questions.text: What is the accounting treatment of owner withdrawals?
Which of the following would not appear on an income statement?
What is the effect of a credit to an expense account?
Which financial statement shows a company's financial position at a specific point in time?
What is the normal balance of an asset account?
What is the normal balance of a liability account?
What is the normal balance of a revenue account?
What is the normal balance of an expense account?

Which inventory costing method assumes first items purchased are first sold?
Which inventory costing method assumes last items purchased are first sold?
What is the allowance for doubtful accounts?
Bad debt expense is recorded to:
options: Match uncollectible accounts with related sales

options: Accumulated net income not distributed as dividends

What is cost of goods sold (COGS)?
options: Direct costs of producing goods sold

questions.text: Gross profit is calculated as:
options: Net Sales - Cost of Goods Sold

questions.text: Which of the following is a period cost?
Which of the following is a product cost?

options: The business will be sold soon
The business will continue operating indefinitely

questions.text: The cost principle requires assets to be recorded at:
The full disclosure principle requires:
The conservatism principle suggests:
options: When in doubt, choose the option that understates assets or income

questions.text: The consistency principle requires:
options: Using the same accounting methods from period to period

questions.text: What is the difference between taxable income and accounting income?
options: Tax rules may differ from GAAP

What is the primary purpose of an audit?
options: To provide assurance on financial statement accuracy

questions.text: An unqualified audit opinion indicates:
options: The financial statements are materially misstated
The auditor could not complete the audit
The financial statements are fairly presented

questions.text: What is a chart of accounts?
options: A list of all accounts used by a business

questions.text: Deposits in transit are:
options: Deposits made but not yet recorded by the bank

options: Include a formal written promise to pay with interest

options: At the end of the accounting period

options: Salaries earned by employees but not yet paid

options: Only one debit and one credit

options: All employees do the same job

options: IFRS is only for US companies
